intro: [WRONG START] Pterocephalus sarawachanicus, commonly known as the Sarawak skullcap, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its distinctive, elongated, and often twisted fruit capsules. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh climatic conditions. Its flowers are small and clustered, often appearing in umbels, and it produces a unique, aromatic scent. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
